item.title: Binary
item.description: Binary Difficulty Levels Bittit Account Recovery Set User ID Format String Exploitation CorROPtion, please! Shrunk-Chunk Heap Overflow Binary Binary exploitation is the process of subverting a compiled application such that it violates some trust boundary in a way that is advantageous to the attacker. It comes down by abusing vulnerabilities that corrupt memory in software or by finding a vulnerability in the program and exploiting it in order to escalate privileges.

item.title: Cryptography
item.description: Cryptography Difficulty Levels JS Crypto Client MD5 Collision Course Lurking in the shadows SSH Vigenère Vignette Cryptography The main goal is usually to crack or clone cryptographic objects or algorithms to reach the flag. Difficulty Levels The levels of difficulty scale is based on the number of steps required in order to solve the Training Challenge Very Easy​: It requires just one step in order to get the flag Easy:​ It requires one-two steps, it is based on the challenge category Medium​: It requires two-three steps, it is based on the challenge category Hard: ​It requires three-four steps based on the challenge category Very Hard:​ It requires several steps in order to get the flag JS Crypto Client Points: ​ 10 Difficulty: Easy

item.title: Forensics
item.description: Forensics Difficulty Levels Network sniffing Web server login Network scanning SSHtay HYDRAted Telnet Stream and Login Git logs FTP server login Man in the Middle Steganography Doormat Steganography Steganography Slam Linux walk-through Translator Android Permission Abuse Android Phishing Login Page Man in the Middle Steganography Doormat Steganography Steganography Slam Linux walk-through Translator Android Permission Abuse Android Phishing Login Page Forensics This is a broad category that includes different types of training challenges such as file format analysis, steganography, memory dump analysis, or network packet capture analysis.

item.title: Reverse Engineering
item.description: Reverse Engineering Difficulty Levels Weird Code Conditional Reverse Engineering Reverse APK PWN_strings C0ffee 0verfl0w Reverse Engineering It is typically the process of taking a compiled (machine code, bytecode) program and converting it back into a more human readable format. Difficulty Levels The levels of difficulty scale is based on the number of steps required in order to solve the Training Challenge Very Easy​: It requires just one step in order to get the flag Easy:​ It requires one-two steps, it is based on the challenge category Medium​: It requires two-three steps, it is based on the challenge category Hard: ​It requires three-four steps based on the challenge category Very Hard:​ It requires several steps in order to get the flag Weird Code Points: ​ 25 Difficulty: Easy

item.title: Web Exploitation
item.description: Web Exploitation Difficulty Levels SQL Injections SQL Injection SQL Users SQL Easy Micro CMS XXS , URL and robots Heartbleed Exposed Logging Login Blogging Cross-Site Request Forgery Phishing Convince visitation of URL Impersonate colleague Abuse Credentials Hijack Domain Cross-Site Scripting Unauthenticated ​Access Remote Access Bust-N-Crack JWT Deeplink Web Exploitation This category includes all the challenges that provide a vulnerable website, from the ones that contains a bug to the ones that run over an old version of a framework.

item.title: A Challenge Struct
item.description: Repository title Describe what the challenge is about, any relevant CVE’s, which tools should be used for the challenge, etc. Domain name If the challenge does not have NMAP as a part of the challenge, the general rule of thumb is, that it should have a domain name. This is to easily distinguish challenges from each other when there is a lot of them running on the platform. The domain name should then also be included in the challenge description(s) for the user to easily access the challenge.

item.title: How to Create A Challenge
item.description: Creating a Challenge A challenge is created as a subfolder in its category folder. A sample challenge folder is sample/piece_of_pie/ with the contents below: example/challenge_1/ |-- README.md |-- Dockerfile |-- .gitlab-ci.yml |-- tests `-- test_exploit.py |-- sol/ | `-- exploit.py |-- config (or src) / |-- auto.conf |-- init.sh As above, the challenge folder must have: * The challenge folder should contain following information and main README.md file. You can follow Challenge Repository Structure for an example of how the readme file should be setup for your challenge;
